titleStmt.title: Introduction: Reading Code in the Age of AI

dhq:bio.p: Jeremy Douglass is Associate Professor of English at the University of California, Santa Barbara. He is director of Digital Arts and Humanities Commons, an interdisciplinary co-working space for digital scholarship, pedagogy, and creative practice, and of the Center for Digital Games Research. He is co-author, with Jessica Pressman and Mark C. Marino, of Reading Project: A Collaborative Analysis of William Poundstone’s Project for Tachistoscope {Bottomless Pit} (Iowa UP, 2015), and co-author, with Montfort et. al, of 10 PRINT CHR$(205.5+RND(1)); : GOTO 10 (The MIT Press, 2012). Douglass conducts research on interactive narrative, electronic literature, and games, with a focus on the methods of software studies, critical code studies, and cultural analytics. His work has been supported by the NEH Office of Digital Humanities, MacArthur Foundation, Mellon Foundation, ACLS, Calit2, HASTAC, and NERSC.

Mark C. Marino is a writer and scholar of electronic literature living in Los Angeles. He book Critical Code Studies (MIT 2020) describes the field represented in this special issue. His creative works include “a show of hands” (http://hands.literatronica.net), “Living Will” (http://markcmarino.com/tales/livingwill.html), and “Stravinsky’s Muse.” With Rob Wittig, he is a co-founder of Meanwhile… Netprov Studios (http://meanwhilenetprov.com). His recent work includes “Salt Immortal Sea” (https://jtm.io/static/saltimmortalsea/) and Mrs. Wobbles and the Tangerine House (http://markcmarino.com/mrsw/), a collection of interactive stories he writes with his children. He was one of ten co-authors of 10 PRINT CHR$(205.5+RND(1)); : GOTO 10 (http://10print.org) (MIT 2013) and joined with Jessica Pressman and Jeremy Douglass on Reading Project: A Collaborative Analysis of William Poundstone’s Project for Tachistoscope {Bottomless Pit} (Iowa Press 2015). He is a co-author of the forthcoming book: Inventing ELIZA: How the First Chatbot Shaped the Future of AI. Mark is also the Director of Communication of the Electronic Literature Organization. He currently teaches writing at the University of Southern California where he directs the Humanities and Critical Code Studies Lab (http://haccslab.com), a colaboratory exploring the explication of computer source code. (Full portfolio here: http://markcmarino.com)

docTitle.titlePart: Introduction: Reading Code in the Age of AI

div.head: The State of Code Reading
div.p: If critical code studies calls for the exploration of the interpretation of the extra-functional significance of computer source code (Marino 2020), if the code is not written by humans or cannot be accessed by them, can it still have meaning? Our short answer is yes.

Since the publication of our first special issue on critical code studies, the world of coding has gone through another tectonic shift. Whereas critical code studies has been helping people to see that code is read by more than just machines, the advent of copilot, cursor, and other generative AI platforms has appeared to move people away from code or at least the need to know how to write it. The reality may prove just the opposite as programmers need to spend more time trying to understand code they did not author directly, and as those who might never have thought to interact with code find themselves generating whole programs. Letting the hype waves roll in and back out again, we take this spread of generative AI as all the more reason to encourage the critical examination of computer source code.

Although Large Language Models (LLMs) were already in use in the digital humanities, 2022 saw the arrival of ChatGPT, bringing the technology to the attention of the broader public, not least of all to the world of coding. Actually, Microsoft had already added Copilot to Github in 2021 (Novet 2021) and then in 2023 released Copilot X, which brought the ability to chat about code to the Visual Studio Code sidebar (Horton 2024). Whether in standalone projects like Cursor or in plugins to IDEs or even just in the code features of Claude, these LLMs changed the way programmers and nonprogrammers alike were interacting with code. When Andrej Karpathy (2025) coined the phrase “Vibe coding” in a post on X, he named a now widespread practice of coding through prompting.

At the same time, LLMs offer unprecedented access to code. Though by no means perfect, LLMs offer readers a chance to explore code with the assistance of a tool that can produce explanations for some of the functioning of the code. Also, since LLMs can be prompted with the language of critical code studies, they can also generate suggestions for code readings. David Berry (2025) has published some initial reflections on rapidly coding through an LLM in an article on “AI Sprints.” Titaÿna Kauffmann (2025) has experimented with using LLMs to perform a critical code studies reading on code from the Apple Lisa with the assistance of LLMs. Testing out this method on the Apollo Lunar Lander code, we have discovered a great potential for helping illuminate the code but also various limits of this approach. Through these experiments, one thing becomes clear: since LLMs can process both code and natural language, it is not bound by the conceptual divisions that often inhibit human readers from bringing these worlds together. Perhaps that freedom of a machine that does not have human understanding, will inspire code readers who do.

The danger is that the transition to machine learning and neural networks will leave software in a new black box, or cloistered as Marta Perez-Campos (2024) argues. In her talk she traces the rise in critical attention on software and code followed by a period where “it is practically impossible to see where the object comes from materially speaking” (176), an obscurity that only attentive critical archaeology and analysis can overcome . In the Humanities and Critical Code Studies Lab, we continue the work of applying Critical Code Studies methods to the study of AI as we did in the article “Can Open-Source Fix Predictive Policing? Anti-Racist Critical Code Studies Approach to Contemporary AI Policing Software” (Ciston, Mann, Marino, Douglass 2025). Though LLMs tend to move code into an area of obscurity, the close reading techniques (either with the assistance of machines or merely creative methods of approach) offer a way to keep this code, and those who generate it, accountable for its effects.

The Critical Code Studies Working Groups continue to develop and explore the possible methodologies. Recent Working Groups have explored Queering Code as well as Teaching Critical Code studies. The latest Working Group (CCSWG26) “Where is the ‘critical’ in critical code studies?”, reflecting on the fields’ emphasis on interpretation, analysis, inflected by philosophical hermeneutics and other forms of critical theory. CCSWG26 will also explore the UNESCO special exhibit of source code, sponsored by the Software Heritage Foundation (now celebrating its 10th year), which pays tribute to influential code around the world (Fichen 2025). The exhibition is organized by Mathilde Fichen, Titaÿna Kauffmann, and Camille Picard. The exhibition committee includes representatives of museums that promote software archaeology and the preservation of code, including David C. Brock of the Computer History Museum, Mountain View, California; Pierre Depaz of Staatliche Hochschule für Gestaltung Karlsruhe; Valérie Schafer of University of Luxembourg; Bostjan Spetic of the Slovenian computer museum; Artemis Yagou of Deutsches Museum; and Stefano Penge of Codexpo.org, “the first source code museum" (Penge 2025) We name these institutions and scholars by way of emphasizing the growing number of institutions and curators interested in preserving computer source code in recognition of its historical cultural significance.

Archaeological explorations of code continue to draw scholars from disparate disciplines and interests. Maybe the most substantive code reading to emerge from the working groups is a collaborative close reading of the source code of ELIZA, the first chatbot. The DOCTOR script, published in 1966, has been the center of several discussions of the working group, but in 2021, a group secured the source code to ELIZA itself, the system on which the DOCTOR script runs (Berry and Marino 2024). Reading that code launched a four-year collaborative reading of the source code by an eclectic group of scholars, artists, philosophers, and programmers (and various combinations of those). That project has also extended into an effort to reanimate the code, using the original MAD-SLIP source material as the basis, a new pathway of code archaeological study (Lane et al. 2025).

A few recent interventions invite conversations about the way code operates in culture and across languages. Alan F. Blackwell’s Moral Codes: Designing Alternatives to AI (2024) calls for better programming languages for the flourishing of human culture. Equally idealistic is Wikimedia’s project to make a function repository and platform that is more language independent. The project is called Wikilamda, and Michael Falk offers a thoughtful critique through the methods of critical code studies. The work to theorize code is not complete either. Brian Lennon’s book Programming Language Cultures (2024) computer languages as a means more of automation than communication. Attempts to theorize code, to make code better for culture, or even to democratize programming show how computer source code continues to be a productive site for the theorization of the digital, for ideological discourse, and for the struggle to contest oppression and achieve social ideals.

Artists continue to contribute insights to critical code studies through their making. Daniel Temkin, for example, who contributed The Less Humble Programmer to our first issue, has since published a book of 44 Esolangs (2025) offers the titular number of original esoteric programming languages. Koundinya Dhulipaya (2025) has also applied a critical code studies approach with decolonial theory to read Prāsa, an esoteric programming language based on the Telugu poetic system of chandassu. Other artists of code, like Nick Montfort (2025), continue to write and publish experiments in code poetics. His Narcissystem describes itself in 1s and 0s. Montfort explains the process, “Go through each line, describing each token. For each, describe the ASCII characters that constitute it. For each, enumerate the eight bits that are used to represent it.” Other artists such as Winnie Soon and Mez Breeze continue to iterate on their long-standing practice of making and manipulating code and code-like languages. These artists working in code both perform and identify the creative possibilities of making in the medium.

Other scholars have found new places to apply critical code studies. For example, Aman Abhishek and Lucas Graves (2024) apply critical code studies to data journalism. Christopher Koch Andersen (2025) has been exploring ways of responding to the violence algorithms bring against trans bodies. Looking at the way we personify algorithms in contemporary life, Gabriele de Seta (2024) has been exploring “algorithmic folklore.”

Scholars continue to include code in their studies of other objects. Tom Boellstorff and Braxton Soderman (2024) have published an extensive study of Intellivision in a book subtitled “How a Videogame System Battled Atari and Almost Bankrupted Barbie®.” That book includes code from the system, once again showing how interdependent platform and code studies are.

Into the current research on the meaning of code and culture, we offer this second special issue of work in critical code studies, a collection that will certainly shape the ways in which code is discussed and interpreted. The essays show the continuing creativity and critical insight that human and humanities-driven exploration of code, at times augmented with software tools. These essays challenge foundational divisions between hardware and software, they reassert the centrality of state, and they explore the complexities of natural language in code. Their methods draw upon media archaeology, rhetoric, history, and more technical methods of science and technology studies. Their approaches introduce new processes of approaching code from defactoring to reading the code aloud. Collected together they offer inspiration and provocations, corrections and new directions for future explorations.

div.head: In This Issue
div.p: This special issue builds on and expands the scope of the work from special issue 1. Whether in their object of study or methodology, each essay offers a new model for how to perform critical code studies.

Because critical code studies pays special attention to the signs of code, readings often explore the proximity of those signs to natural language. Kevin Brock offers a foundational discussion of “Naming in Code,” arguing that the practice of using natural language, whether in keywords, functions, or variable names grows out of procedural habit to achieve specific rhetorical goals. However, the presence of natural language false cognates, or misleading homonyms, can lead to misunderstandings. In “Polysemicolon; Novice Programmers and Java Keywords,” Brianna Bettin discusses the challenges of “false cognates” in programming, keywords or reserved words that mislead newcomers to a programming language. In these two readings, natural language complements and complicates the reading of code.

Central to these readings is archaeological work, examining the evolution of code in its historical context. Returning to the earliest conception of computers, Zachary Mann employs critical code studies to examine the work of Ada Lovelace. Exploring the more recent past, Zachary Horton and Levi Burner explore coding on the Magnavox Odyssey game console, emphasizing the interconnectedness of code, context, and console. In their reading, further complicating the program-plaform division, the console hardware becomes a means of programming. Both of these essays lavish their attention on the details and documentation of these material histories while also attending their social implications.

Critical code studies aims to reveal what has become obscured. Evan Buswell makes a compelling argument that in representing knowledge as process, code represses or obscures the fundamental role of state. Buswell’s work redresses this fundamental “epistemic inadequacy” in a foundational gesture that affects all critical code studies. Exploring the mechanisms of sentiment analysis in TextBlob, Jeffrey Moro traces its roots to argue that the software does not reveal affect but instead creates it. His work challenges the naturalization of computational judgement, unsettling an algorithmic assessment of the kind that holds so much sway in data-centered discourse.

How we read code, how we access it, is just as pivotal to how we interpret it. This issue introduces new methods of performing critical code studies. Matt Burton and Joris Van Zundert present “Defactoring” as a method, demonstrating the critical affordances of using a code notebook for exploring an extensive body of code, while Katrine Meldgaard Kjær and Mace Ojala demonstrate the practice of reading code aloud. While Defactoring attempts to render the code more legible by reorganizing it into a narrative structure, reading code aloud listens for the evocations of the sound of the code.

Each of these articles offers methods and conceptualisms as models for performing code readings and frameworks for new explorations. They offer foundational gestures as well as provocative new directions which we expect will have lasting impact on the next wave of scholarship in this field.

We continue to feel gratitude not just for the many scholars who continue to develop this field that if not nascent is still only in its toddling days, finding its footing, learning how to navigate both ground and obstacles even as it shifts. And a great deal of that gratitude goes to Digital Humanities Quarterly, its editors and production team and especially Julia Flanders who has made DHQ a home for CCS. We look forward to the future work in critical code studies that scholars will publish under its banner.
